net.alexanderdev.lightdrive.graphics

Class GraphicsX

  • java.lang.Object
    • net.alexanderdev.lightdrive.graphics.GraphicsX

  • public class GraphicsX
extends java.lang.Object
    A class which encapsulates the functionality of Graphics2D, while adding or modifying methods for more convenient drawing abilities.

    Such additions and modifications include:
    • Drawing text which is aligned relative to a Rectangle
    • Drawing text which takes new-line characters into consideration
    • Drawing text with it's characters spaced out
    • Drawing text from the top-left corner, instead of the baseline
    • Drawing images without the need for an ImageObserver
    • Drawing images that are scaled to fit within a Rectangle
    • Getting and setting Font attributes separately
    • Setting the color with a '0xAARRGGBB' formatted integer color value
    Since:
    Apr 24, 2015, 2:32:23 AM
    Author:
    Christian Bryce Alexander
    See Also:
    Graphics2D

      void drawString(java.lang.String str, float x, float y)
      Draws a string as specified by drawString(String, float, float, float, float), with a default character spacing of 0.
      void drawString(java.lang.String str, float x, float y, float xs, float ys)
      Delegates to the method of the same name, found in Graphics2D.drawString(String, float, float).

      As stated in the class description, this method is rewritten so that text is drawn from the top left of the string, instead of from the baseline, all new-line characters cause the string to be drawn a line below the one before, and it incorporates vertical and horizontal spacing between characters.

      As stated in the class description, this method is rewritten so that text is drawn from the top left of the string, instead of from the baseline, all new-line characters cause the string to be drawn a line below the one before, and it incorporates vertical and horizontal spacing between characters.

        img - The image to draw
        bounds - The bounds to scale to

      • drawString

        public void drawString(java.text.AttributedCharacterIterator iterator,
                       float x,
                       float y)
        Delegates to the method of the same name, found in Graphics2D.drawString(AttributedCharacterIterator, float, float).

        As stated in the class description, this method is rewritten so that text is drawn from the top left of the string, instead of from the baseline.

      • drawString

        public void drawString(java.lang.String str,
                       float x,
                       float y)
        Draws a string as specified by drawString(String, float, float, float, float), with a default character spacing of 0.

      • drawString

        public void drawString(java.lang.String str,
                       float x,
                       float y,
                       float xs,
                       float ys)
        Delegates to the method of the same name, found in Graphics2D.drawString(String, float, float).

        As stated in the class description, this method is rewritten so that text is drawn from the top left of the string, instead of from the baseline, all new-line characters cause the string to be drawn a line below the one before, and it incorporates vertical and horizontal spacing between characters.

      • drawString

        public void drawString(java.lang.String str,
                       int x,
                       int y)
        Draws a string as specified by drawString(String, int, int, int, int), with a default character spacing of 0.

                       int y,
                       int xs,
                       int ys)
        Delegates to the method of the same name, found in Graphics.drawString(String, int, int).

        As stated in the class description, this method is rewritten so that text is drawn from the top left of the string, instead of from the baseline, all new-line characters cause the string to be drawn a line below the one before, and it incorporates vertical and horizontal spacing between characters.
